conversation.content: [cautiously] The lawyer said the property deed is clear—my grandmother left everything to me, but nobody mentioned anything about you working this land or any arrangement you might have had.

[measured] Your grandmother and I shook hands on it fifteen years ago when my father died and left me nothing. She said I could work this land as long as I maintained her flower gardens and the old olive trees.
[skeptical] Fifteen years?

[gently] Every spring I plant the marigolds she loved, trim the roses the way she taught me, and those olive trees produce the best oil in the valley now because I tend them like they're my own children.
That's very touching. [pause]

[earnestly] She used to sit right there on that stone bench every evening while I worked, telling me stories about you, about your studies in the city, how proud she was that you were the first in the family to go to university.
[softer] She talked about me? I barely visited these last few years with all the exams and internships, and honestly I thought she'd forgotten I existed.

[warmly] Forgotten? She kept every letter you sent in a box by her bed, read them to me sometimes when her eyes got too weak to read alone. [chuckles] I know about your thesis on sustainable agriculture.
[surprised] You know about my thesis? That's actually—wait, she read my academic work to you? Those papers were incredibly technical and boring.
Not boring at all. [sighs]
Look, I understand you've been here a long time, but legally speaking, without documentation, I need to figure out what's fair here.

[carefully] Fair would be letting me show you what I've built here—the irrigation system I installed, the greenhouse where I grow her heirloom tomatoes, the ledger where I recorded every harvest, every expense, every coin I set aside for her care.
[intrigued] You kept financial records? For fifteen years? Most of the farmers here don't even—I mean, that's surprisingly thorough for someone without formal education.

Your grandmother taught me the numbers, said if I was going to work her land properly, I needed to understand more than just soil and seasons. [quietly] She believed in me when nobody else would give me work.
[thoughtfully] She taught you accounting? That does sound like her, always trying to lift people up, though I never knew she was quite so hands-on about it.
Hands-on, yes. [laughs softly]
[decisively] Show me these ledgers, and the improvements you mentioned—I want to understand exactly what you've done here before we discuss any arrangements going forward.
Thank you.
[firmly] But I'm not promising anything yet, you understand? I need to see everything first, verify the numbers, maybe consult with some agricultural assessors about the actual value added.

[respectfully] Of course, that's wise, and I have nothing to hide—every seed planted, every tree pruned, it's all there in black and white, just as your grandmother insisted. [pause] She always said you'd come back one day.

scenario: A recent university graduate returns to their ancestral village to settle their grandmother's estate and discovers the peasant farmer working the land based on an undocumented fifteen-year verbal agreement.
